channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Serbia’s Ruling Pro-European Party Appears Headed for a Win
item.media:description: A Kosovar Serb couple preparing to cast votes in the town of Gracanica on Sunday. Voter turnout was about 55 percent.
item.description: Prime Minister Aleksandar Vucic has said he plans to use a victory to push through reforms needed for the country to join the European Union.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW MACDOWALL

item.title: Austrian Presidential Vote Gives Edge to Right-Wing Candidate
item.media:description: Norbert Hofer of the anti-immigration Freedom Party in Vienna after the first-round of voting for president on Sunday. The country’s two main parties failed to make it into a runoff next month.
item.description: Norbert Hofer of the anti-immigration Freedom Party was the leader in the first round of voting, winning 35 percent of the ballots. A runoff is set for May 22.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Turkey’s Crackdown on Critics of Erdogan Snares Dutch Journalist
item.media:description: The Dutch journalist Ebru Umar on Sunday in Kusadasi, Turkey, after the Turkish police detained her for criticizing President Recep Tayyip Erdogan.
item.media:credit: Ihlas News Agency/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: The detention of Ebru Umar, who was taken from her summer home for questioning, was the latest action against writers and others who have insulted President Recep Tayyip Erdogan.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO

item.title: Missing Mexican Students Suffered a Night of ‘Terror,’ Investigators Say
item.media:description: Portraits of some of the 43 missing students, in Chilpancingo, the capital of Guerrero State. The reason for their abduction remains a mystery.
item.description: An international panel has provided details of the night in 2014 when Mexican police and gunmen abducted 43 students who have not been seen since.
item.dc:creator: KIRK SEMPLE
item.category: Escuela Normal Rural Raul Isidro Burgos (Guerrero, Mexico)

item.title: Inquiry Challenges Mexico’s Account of How 43 Students Vanished
item.media:description: Relatives of the students, with signs that read “We are missing 43.”
item.description: Five suspects whose testimony underpinned the government’s conclusions gave confessions “under torture or cruel, inhumane or degrading treatment,” a report by international experts found.
item.dc:creator: KIRK SEMPLE and ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: Failure to Share Data Hampers War on Boko Haram in Africa
item.media:description: Soldiers from the Rapid Intervention Brigade operated a surveillance drone at their base in Achigachia, Cameroon, last month.
item.description: American intelligence services have struggled at times to provide information quickly about militants without violating restrictions on what can be shared.
item.dc:creator: ERIC SCHMITT and DIONNE SEARCEY
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: ISIS Targeted by Cyberattacks in a New U.S. Line of Combat
item.media:description: Adm. Michael S. Rogers, the commander of Cyber Command and the director of the National Security Agency, testifying before the Senate Armed Services Committee this month in Washington.
item.description: The military has been told to mount computer-network attacks against the group, which has proved effective at modern communications and encryption.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Yemeni Troops, Backed by United Arab Emirates, Take City From Al Qaeda
item.media:description: Forces supporting Yemen’s government patrolled a street in Lahj, a southern province west of Al Mukalla, as part of an effort to push out Qaeda fighters.
item.description: The loss of Al Mukalla was a blow to Al Qaeda’s Yemeni branch, which had controlled the southern city for more than a year and used it as a base.
item.dc:creator: SAEED AL-BATATI, KAREEM FAHIM and ERIC SCHMITT
item.category: Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula

item.title: Dulong Journal: Chinese Modernization Comes to an Isolated People
item.media:description: A family of ethnic Dulong in Qinlandang, the last village before the border with Myanmar.
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.description: A pristine valley in Yunnan Province, home to the ethnic Dulong people, is seeing progress in the name of alleviating poverty and drawing tourists.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: Israel Frees Palestinian Girl, 12, Who Tried to Stab Guard
item.media:description: Dima al-Wawi, 12, was comforted by her mother, Sabha al-Wawi, at a checkpoint near the West Bank town of Tulkarm on Sunday after her release from an Israeli prison for trying to stab a security guard.
item.description: Dima al-Wawi, the youngest known Palestinian inmate, was released weeks early and greeted with a hero’s welcome in her West Bank hometown.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: Orphanage Founder From Africa Wins Prize in Memory of Armenian Genocide
item.media:description: Marguerite Barankitse accepted the inaugural Aurora Prize for Awakening Humanity from Ruben Vardanyan, one of the award’s creators, at left, and George Clooney, who was a co-chairman of the selection committee, at the presentation Sunday in Yerevan, Armenia.
item.description: Marguerite Barankitse defied death threats and saw unspeakable violence as she saved thousands of children from ethnic slaughters in the 1990s.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: White House Letter: No Need for Holmes. Obama Sheds Light on a Winston Churchill Mystery.
item.media:description: President George W. Bush in the Oval Office of the White House in 2008, with a bust of Winston Churchill behind him.
item.media:credit: Brendan Smialowski for The New York Times
item.description: The president may have cleared up a subject of confusion: what happened to a bust of the British prime minister that was in the Oval Office.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL D. SHEAR

item.title: Politico Pierces the ‘Brussels Bubble’ With U.S.-Style Coverage
item.media:description: Ryan Heath, a senior correspondent at Politico, writes the Brussels Playbook, a popular newsletter.
item.media:credit: Cedric Gerbehaye for The New York Times
item.description: The European outpost of the American political publication is bringing flood-the-zone reporting to the heart of the E.U., rankling some in the establishment.
item.dc:creator: NICOLA CLARK

item.title: Obama Joins Angela Merkel in Pushing Trade Deal to a Wary Germany
item.media:description: Mr. Obama and Ms. Merkel in Hanover on Sunday. Ms. Merkel is among Mr. Obama’s closest and most trusted counterparts.
item.description: Standing next to Chancellor Merkel in Hanover, President Obama said the benefits of a new trans-Atlantic trade deal were “indisputable.”
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE and MICHAEL D. SHEAR

item.title: Obama Calls Meeting With European Leaders Over Shared Challenges
item.media:description: President Obama at a town-hall-style meeting on Saturday in London, where he took questions on a variety of topics.
item.description: The meeting comes amid a growing sense in the administration that Europe is faltering in the face of multiple challenges, undercutting the trans-Atlantic alliance.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER and MICHAEL D. SHEAR

item.title: Turkey’s Seizure of Churches and Land Alarms Armenians
item.media:description: A Turkish police officer in February during clashes with protestors demonstrating against government imposed curfews in February in Diyarbakir, Turkey.
item.description: The diaspora and rights groups have been unnerved by expropriations in Diyarbakir, where the government is fighting militants and where, it says, it will return properties after restoration is complete.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: Egyptian Police Official Files Complaint Against Reuters
item.description: The news agency reported that Giulio Regeni, an Italian graduate student, was in police custody before his death, a claim that law enforcement officials have denied.
item.dc:creator: KAREEM FAHIM and NOUR YOUSSEF

item.title: Earthquake Jolts Ecuador Into Enacting Long-Avoided Fiscal Changes
item.media:description: A funeral is held for a family that was killed in the earthquake while they were shopping for school supplies.
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.description: After the country’s largest quake since 1979, its leftist leaders are turning to the kinds of measures they rose to power railing against.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS CASEY

item.title: Ireland Seeks Peaceful Path to Marking 1916 Easter Rising
item.media:description: Irish republicans commemorated the Easter Rising in Londonderry, Northern Ireland, in March.
item.description: A critical, deadly episode in the quest for independence remains divisive 100 years on. Some see undemocratic treachery; others, heroism.
item.dc:creator: DOUGLAS DALBY

item.title: A Respite of Soccer for Qatar’s Laborers
item.media:description: Fans of Gulf Contracting, a construction firm working in Qatar that advanced to the May 6 final of the Workers Cup in a shootout.
item.media:credit: Olya Morvan for The New York Times
item.description: The players in the four-year-old Workers Cup are just a fraction of the thousands of migrant workers who are actively building Qatar into a modern state.
item.dc:creator: JAMES MONTAGUE
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Chernobyl’s Silent Exclusion Zone (Except for the Logging)
item.media:description: A boot overgrown with moss in the Chernobyl exclusion zone in Ukraine. Moss is best avoided, a guide said. It can be radioactive.
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: Thirty years later, there are signs of commercial clear-cutting in supposedly off-limits forests around the site of the nuclear disaster in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: North Korea Fires Ballistic Missile From Submarine, South Says
item.description: The missile flew only 19 miles, a flight too short to be called a successful launch, South Korea’s Office of Joint Chiefs of Staff said in a statement.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Obama, in London, Urges Support for European Trade Deal
item.media:description: President Obama spoke during a town-hall-style meeting at the Royal Horticultural Halls in London on Saturday.
item.description: At a town-hall-style meeting, President Obama said the deal between the United States and Europe could still protect workers and the environment.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL D. SHEAR

item.title: Bangladesh Police Suspect Islamist Militants in Professor’s Killing
item.media:description: A photograph of Rezaul Karim Siddiquee, a professor who was killed in Rajshahi, Bangladesh, on Saturday.
item.media:credit: Md. Abdullah Iqbal/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Rezaul Karim Siddiquee, 61, a professor of English, was nearly beheaded in the attack near his home on Saturday, the police said.
item.dc:creator: JULFIKAR ALI MANIK and ELLEN BARRY

item.title: In Spain, Catching Up With Cervantes
item.media:description: Members of Factoria Teatro performing parts of Cervantes’s “The Spanish-English Lady” on the Madrid subway this month.
item.description: State-sponsored events to honor the writer on the 400th anniversary of his death fall short, critics say.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Syrian Airstrikes Kill at Least 25
item.description: The government says it is targeting only terrorist groups not covered by a cease-fire, but some warned that the deal was in danger of collapsing.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Editorial: In Norway, a Victory for the Rule of Law
item.description: A mass murderer sues and tests the country’s commitment to human rights.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Opinion: Frozen Life in Wartime Syria
item.media:description: An elementary school in Aleppo, Syria, damaged in fighting. Five years of civil war has put Syrians’ lives on hold.
item.description: What does survival look like for the million people behind siege lines with no sugar, no power and little hope?
item.dc:creator: JANINE DI GIOVANNI
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: In Ecuador, Political Aftershocks
item.media:description: Rescue workers search for survivors in Portoviejo, Ecuador.
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.description: With the country reeling from a devastating earthquake, the most effective relief efforts have come from citizens, not the government.
item.dc:creator: MARTIN PALLARES

item.title: Alissa Rubin, 2016 Pulitzer Winner, Reports From the Front Lines
item.media:description: Alissa Rubin
item.description: Ms. Rubin has spent much of her career covering Iraq, Afghanistan and the Balkans.
item.dc:creator: MIKE McPHATE

item.title: Lens Blog: Photography Pulitzer for Coverage of Refugee Crisis
item.description: The New York Times and Thomson Reuters shared the Pulitzer Prize for breaking news photography for coverage of Europe’s refugee crisis. Jessica Rinaldi of the Boston Globe won the feature photography prize for her story of a boy who endured abuse at the hands of those he trusted.
item.dc:creator: DAVID GONZALEZ and JAMES ESTRIN

item.title: Dispatch from Dakar: ‘Where Is This Flight Going?’ and Other Basic Questions About African Travel
item.media:description: A moldy airplane on the runway in Cameroon.
item.description: In West Africa, getting there is way more than half the battle.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY

item.title: How ISIS Built the Machinery of Terror Under Europe’s Gaze
item.media:description: The Paris attacks left 130 dead in November, but a branch within the Islamic State was obsessed with striking Europe at least two years before then.
item.description: Two years before the Paris and Brussels assaults, a special branch of the group was churning out smaller attacks that the authorities repeatedly discounted as isolated or random acts.
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
